raw_text:
Orange colour clash set for court
 
 A row over the colour orange could hit the courts after mobile phone giant Orange launched action against a new mobile venture from Easyjet's founder.
 
 Orange said it was starting proceedings against the Easymobile service for trademark infringement. Easymobile uses Easygroup's orange branding. Founder Stelios Haji-Ioannou has pledged to contest the action. The move comes after the two sides failed to come to an agreement after six months of talks. Orange claims the new low-cost mobile service has infringed its rights regarding the use of the colour orange and could confuse customers - known as "passing off".
 
 "Our brand, and the rights associated with it are extremely important to us," Orange said in a statement. "In the absence of any firm commitment from Easy, we have been left with no choice but to start an action for trademark infringement and passing off." However, Mr Haji-Ioannou, who plans to launch Easymobile next month, vowed to fight back, saying: "We have nothing to be afraid of in this court case. "It is our right to use our own corporate colour for which we have become famous during the last 10 years." The Easyjet founder also said he planned to add a disclaimer to the Easygroup website to ensure customers are aware the Easymobile brand has no connection to Orange. The new service is the latest venture from Easygroup, which includes a chain of internet cafes, budget car rentals and an intercity bus service. Easymobile will allow customers to go online to order SIM cards and airtime - which will be rented from T-Mobile - for their existing handsets.
llama3.2:1b: Orange has launched action against Easyjet founder Stelios Haji-Ioannou's new mobile venture, Easymobile, over trademark infringement and passing off. Orange claims the new service uses its orange branding without permission and could confuse customers. The two parties failed to come to an agreement after six months of talks.
llama3.2:3b: Orange is suing Easymobile, the new low-cost mobile venture from Easyjet's founder Stelios Haji-Ioannou, over trademark infringement, claiming the use of orange branding could confuse customers and infringe on its rights regarding the color orange.
gemma2:2b: Orange has filed a lawsuit against Easymobile for trademark infringement, claiming the new mobile venture uses its orange branding and could confuse customers.  Easymobile founder Stelios Haji-Ioannou plans to contest the lawsuit, stating his right to use his own corporate color after 10 years. He will also add a disclaimer on the Easygroup website to clarify that Easymobile has no connection to Orange.
qwen2.5:0.5b: A court case is being held over Orange's actions against Easyjet for trademark infringement involving the use of the orange colour, as evidenced by the founder's pledge not to fight back.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Orange has filed trademark infringement and passing off lawsuits against Easygroup's new low-cost mobile service, Easymobile, due to its use of orange branding, after failing to reach an agreement with the founder Stelios Haji-Ioannou. The CEO vows not to back down in court while the other party plans to add a disclaimer on their website.
qwen2.5:3b: Orange mobile has initiated legal action against Easymobile over trademark infringement and "passing off" due to color clash with Easygroup's use of orange branding, despite failing to resolve issues through negotiations. Orange claims the new low-cost service could confuse customers using its exclusive orange color. Founder Stelios Haji-Ioannou vows to contest the case, asserting their right to use the color and plans to add a disclaimer. Easymobile is an Easygroup venture offering online SIM card purchases from T-Mobile.
opencoder:1.5b: A row over the orange could hit the courts after mobile phone giant Orange launched action against a new mobile venture from Easyjet's founder. The company says it was starting proceedings against trademark infringement, uses its orange branding, and agrees to contest the case. The move comes after the two sides failed to come to an agreement after six months of talks. The statement also highlights its brand commitment to customers' privacy. The Easyjet founder mentioned plans to add a disclaimer on their website.
smollm:1.7b: The Orange colour clash set for court is the starting point of the summary. The action taken by Orange against Easymobile, a mobile venture from Easyjet's founder, is mentioned first. Then, the dispute with Easyjet is introduced as well as the new low-cost mobile service that has infringed on Orange's rights regarding the use of the colour orange. The claim for trademark infringement and passing off are also mentioned. The summary ends with a statement about the Orange brand and its importance to Orange, followed by the launch of Easymobile next month.

Alright, I need to help the user by summarizing the given text concisely while preserving key ideas and details. The user has specified that only the summary should be provided in plain text without any explanations, formatting, or reasoning.

First, I'll read through the original text carefully to understand all the important points. 

The main points are:
1. Orange color clash could affect court proceedings after launching a legal action against Easymobile.
2. Easymobile uses Easygroup's orange branding.
3. Mr. Haji-Ioannou, Easymobile's founder, has pledged to contest the action.
4. The move is based on confusion caused by "passing off" oranges as brand colors.
5. There have been six months of talks without progress, leading to Orange starting proceedings.
6. Orange mentioned its brand rights are crucial and they might lose if no commitment from Easy.

I should condense all these points into a concise summary that includes each key element without any additional information or explanation. I'll make sure to avoid any extra details beyond the essentials.

Let me structure it: start with the color clash affecting court, mention Orange's action against Easymobile, Haji-Ioannou's commitment, the basis of confusion, past talks' lack of progress, and the brand rights aspect. That should cover all necessary information succinctly.
</think>

A row over the orange color could impact court proceedings after Orange launched an action against a new mobile service Easymobile from Easyjet's founder, Mr. Haji-Ioannou. The move is based on confusion caused by "passing off" oranges as brand colors. Mr. Haji-Ioannou has pledged to contest the action, while Orange claims its brand rights are crucial and might lose if no commitment from Easy is made. Easymobile uses Easygroup's orange branding, and the service will allow online transactions with handsets that include SIM cards and airtime rented from T-Mobile.
tinyllama:1.1b: Orange has launched a new mobile venture, Easygroup, but the company is taking legal action against a new mobile service provider named Easymobilee for trademark infirmation and passing off. The two sides failed to agree on terms, leading Orange to launch legal proceedings, which could lead to customers not understanding that the new low-cost mobile service has infused their brand's color "oraing" and will use it as a logo or slogan. The company claims Easygroup's new mobile venture is infringing on their rights regarding "oraing", and that they have no choice but to start an action for trademark infirmation and passing off against the service provider. In response, Easygroup plans to add a disclaimer to their website to ensure customers are aware that the new mobile venture has nothing to do with Orange's brand.
tinydolphin:1.1b: In the recent court case, mobile phone company Orange has launched legal action against a new mobile venture called Easymobile, claiming that the service uses its brand orange in a way it doesn't approve of. The suit is about trademark infringement and passing off, which could confuse customers who might think their usage of the orange color represents Orange's brand or affiliated entities. However, Stelios Haji-Ioannou, founder of Easyjet, aims to fight back by adding a disclaimer to Easygroup's website. This move comes after six months of talks between Easymobile and Orange, but with no agreement in sight, it appears that the dispute will go to court.

The two sides had failed to reach an agreement after six months of talks. Orange claims that the new low-cost mobile service may confuse customers and infringe its rights. Mr Haji-Ioannou has vowed to fight back, stating that he planned to add a disclaimer to the website to ensure customers are aware of the lack of connection between Easygroup and Orange. The new venture is called Easymobile and will allow customers to order SIM cards and airtime for their existing handsets from T-Mobile.

The Easymobile brand has no connection to Orange, but founder Stelios Haji-Ioannou vows to fight back in court. The two sides have failed to reach an agreement; Haji-Ioannou plans to contest the action and add a disclaimer to Easygroup's website to clarify the relationship between Easymobile and Orange.
chatgpt-4o-latest: Orange is taking legal action against Easymobile, a new mobile service from Easyjet's founder, for trademark infringement over the use of the colour orange. Orange argues that Easymobile's branding could confuse customers and constitutes "passing off." After six months of failed negotiations, Orange decided to proceed with legal action, emphasizing the importance of protecting its brand. Easymobile's founder, Stelios Haji-Ioannou, vowed to fight the case, asserting his right to use Easygroup's established corporate colour. He also plans to add a disclaimer to clarify that Easymobile is not connected to Orange. Easymobile, set to launch next month, will offer online SIM card and airtime purchases, using T-Mobile's network.
stablelm2:1.6b: Orange is starting trademark infringement proceedings against Easyjet's founder's new mobile venture, Easymobile, due to the use of orange branding. Orange claims the service could confuse customers and infringe its rights regarding the color orange. Despite Orange's claims, founder Stelios Haji-Ioannou plans to launch Easymobile next month with a disclaimer on the Easygroup website to clarify their brand's separation from Orange.
granite3.1-dense:2b: Orange, a mobile phone company, is pursuing legal action against Easyjet's founder Stelios Haji-Ioannou's new venture, Easymobile, due to trademark infringement and potential customer confusion over the use of the colour orange. This dispute stems from six months of unsuccessful negotiations between the parties. Orange asserts that Easymobile's branding violates their rights regarding the colour orange. Haji-Ioannou, founder of Easygroup, which includes various businesses like internet cafes and car rentals, plans to contest the case, emphasizing his group's right to use the iconic orange colour. He intends to add a disclaimer to the Easygroup website to clarify that Easymobile is not affiliated with Orange. The lawsuit centers around Easymobile's provision of SIM cards and airtime for existing T-Mobile users through online orders, marking another venture by Easygroup under Haji-Ioannou's leadership.
reference: Orange claims the new low-cost mobile service has infringed its rights regarding the use of the colour orange and could confuse customers - known as "passing off".Orange said it was starting proceedings against the Easymobile service for trademark infringement.A row over the colour orange could hit the courts after mobile phone giant Orange launched action against a new mobile venture from Easyjet's founder.The Easyjet founder also said he planned to add a disclaimer to the Easygroup website to ensure customers are aware the Easymobile brand has no connection to Orange.Easymobile uses Easygroup's orange branding."Our brand, and the rights associated with it are extremely important to us," Orange said in a statement.
